title: 111_hr2588
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009". It includes provisions for affordable new mortgages. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation are required to purchase and securitize qualified new mortgages on single-family housing as per the Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency's policies. Lenders can offer mortgages for purchase, and if deemed qualified, the enterprises must commit to purchasing them. The enterprise must commit to purchasing qualified new mortgages on single-family housing, where the mortgagor must occupy the property as their principal residence with a fixed interest rate not exceeding 1.6 percentage points. The mortgage for qualified new mortgages on single-family housing must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 1.6 percentage points higher than the average annual rate of interest on U.S. obligations, with a term of 30-40 years from the beginning of amortization. Underwriting standards must be met, and the loan amount must be used for purchasing the property. The mortgage must be originated after the enactment of the Act. Securities based on qualified new mortgages purchased by enterprises must be set aside and approved by the Secretary of the Treasury before issuance and sale. These securities can take the form of debt obligations or trust certificates with determined maturities and interest rates. Securities issued under this subsection are exempt to the same extent as other securities. The subsection allows mortgages to be considered exempt securities, similar to US government-guaranteed securities. Mortgages must always have enough funds set aside for timely payments. Securities issued under this subsection must clearly state they are not US government guaranteed debt. The requirement for enterprises to purchase mortgages does not apply to mortgages offered after two years from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Affordable refinancing of mortgages held by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation are required to carry out a program for refinancing qualified mortgages on single-family housing. The program includes the purchase and securitization of refinancing mortgages, with specific requirements for a mortgage to be considered qualified. The mortgage for a one- to four-family dwelling, including condos or cooperative ownership, must be used to refinance GSE-owned mortgages originated before January 1, 2008. The mortgage must have a fixed interest rate for the entire term. The mortgage must have a fixed interest rate for the entire term, not exceeding 1.6 percentage points higher than the average annual rate of interest on US obligations. Prepayment penalties and fees related to default must be waived. The requirement to refinance qualified mortgages by the enterprises does not apply after two years from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. TREASURY FINANCING. The Secretary has the authority to purchase securities and obligations issued by enterprises for programs under this Act using proceeds from the sale of securities. Obligations purchased will have specific characteristics determined by the Secretary. The Secretary has the authority to purchase securities and obligations issued by enterprises for programs under this Act. The aggregate principal amount of outstanding obligations and securities purchased by the Secretary may not exceed $10,000,000,000. All transactions by the Secretary under this section are treated as public debt transactions of the United States. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS.

Definitions for this Act:
(1) Director - Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency.
(2) Enterprise - Federal National Mortgage Association and Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
(3) Secretary - Secretary of the Treasury.
